child.pub-comments: The Hani language appears twice in this tree because two different sources on Hani were used in the analysis; this node represents Hani as described by Kao Hua-nien (1955).

child.pub-comments: Matisoff shows Phu-noi as part of the Bisuan subgroup with a dotted line (rather than solid), indicating that its membership in the Bisuan group is uncertain (1972: 21).

child.publications: Matisoff, James A. 1972. The Loloish Tonal Split Revisited. Berkeley, CA: Center for South and Southeast Asian Studies.
child.pub-comments: Matisoff shows Pyen as part of the Bisuan subgroup with a dotted line (rather than solid), indicating that its membership in the Bisuan group is uncertain (1972: 21).

child.pub-comments: "Of these fifteen languages, two may immediately be set off from the others on grounds of extreme tonal aberrancy. These are Ch'iang (as described by Wen Yu 1950), which has no phonemic tone at all in isolated syllables; and Moso (sometimes called Na-khi) as described by Li, Chang, and Ho (1967), where the tonal distinctions in stopped syllables are clearly secondary. We therefore group these languages together (they also share a a complex and archaic-looking consonantism) in the Mosoid subgroup and shall worry no further about them in the present context" (Matisoff 1972: 5).

child.pub-comments: Author indicates that there are other descendents of Proto-Tibeto-Burman in addition to Proto-Lolo-Burmese, but does not list them.

root.pub-comments: This tree is based on a reconstruction of the Loloish tonal split (Matisoff 1972).
